choices.text: ≥ 110 mg/dl
≥ 126 mg/dl
≥ 140 mg/dl
≥ 200 mg/dl

questions.text: For diagnosis of overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS] level should be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ≥ 126 mg/dl 

 

IADPSG Recommendations: Testing in 2 phases

 

1st Phase: To test for overt diabetes (which the woman may be unaware of)
 

  • Done in the 1st trimester (early antenatal visit)
  • Test using HbA1C/ FBS/ RBS
  • FBS ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • HbA1C ≥ 6.5 %
  • RBS ≥ 200 mg/dL (but this should be confirmed by FBS/ HbA1C)

 

                       

 

2nd Phase: To test for GDM
 

  • Done between 24 – 28 weeks
  • 75g GTT
  • Fasting: 92/ 1h – 180/ 2h – 153
  • Any one value abnormal: Enough to diagnose GDM

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To diagnose overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS) level should be ≥ 126 mg/dl (milligrams per decilitre).
  • It's important to note that the diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes may vary in different guidelines and regions. However, a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dl is a commonly recognized threshold for diagnosing overt gestational diabetes.

 

 

Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate
Deep tendon reflexes, O2 saturation, consciousness status
O2 saturation, urine output, heart rate
Heart rate, BP, respiratory rate and urine output

questions.text: A 20-year primi presented at 32 weeks with eclampsia. She was started on MgSO4 (Pritchard’s regime) and she delivered after induction of labor. Maintenance dose of MgSO4 was continued for 24 hours. Prevention of Mg toxicity involves monitoring of the following clinical parameters:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate

 

  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Educational Objective

 

The prevention of magnesium toxicity in the management of eclampsia involves careful monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate. Deep tendon reflexes help detect early signs of toxicity, urine output indicates renal function and magnesium clearance, and respiratory rate assesses potential respiratory depression from magnesium sulfate.

 

Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1st edition

choices.text: a, b, c
a, d, e
a, b
a, b, c, d

questions.text:
Which of the following are feature(s) of magnesium toxicity in pregnancy?

 

  1. Loss of deep tendon reflex
  2. Decreased respiratory rate
  3. Decreased urine output
  4. Hypertension
  5. Increased heart rate
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a, b

 

Features of Mg Toxicity are

 

  • Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute)
  • Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema
  • Cardiac arrest
  • O2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%)
  • Double vision
  • Slurred speech
  • Nausea-vomiting
  • Muscular weakness

 

**Decreased urine output is not a feature of Mg toxicity. Renal failure can be seen in severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia and as Mg is excreted through the kidneys, decreased renal function can increase the Mg levels in the blood thereby leading to Mg toxicity.

 

Thus Option C) is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Magnesium Toxicity:

 

  • Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute)
  • Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema
  • Cardiac arrest
  • O2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%)
  • Double vision
  • Slurred speech
  • Nausea-vomiting
  • Muscular weakness

 

**Decreased urine output is not a feature of Mg toxicity. Renal failure can be seen in severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia and as Mg is excreted through the kidneys, decreased renal function can increase the Mg levels in the blood thereby leading to Mg toxicity.

 

Ref: Page no 1880, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Necrotizing enterocolitis
Hyperbilirubinemia
Neonatal hypocalcemia
Neonatal hyperglycemia

questions.text: A 32-years old G3P2L2 visits an antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. She reveals during history that her first baby weighed 4.6 kg, second baby weighed 4.8 kg, and both were delivered by C-section. Neonatal complications of an infant of diabetic mother except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Neonatal hyperglycemia

 

Diabetes mellitus during pregnancy

 

Neonatal complications (Seen because of Pedersen Hypothesis)

 

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Polycythemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Cardiomyopathy

 

Let's discuss the neonatal complications associated with infants of diabetic mothers, to understand why "Neonatal hyperglycemia" is the exception:

 

  1. Necrotizing Enterocolitis (Option A): While not the most common complication in infants of diabetic mothers, necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can occur. NEC is a serious intestinal disease that affects mostly premature infants. Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk for various complications, but NEC is not typically a direct consequence of maternal diabetes.
     
  2. Hyperbilirubinemia (Option B): This is a common complication in infants of diabetic mothers. These infants often have increased red blood cell turnover, which can lead to higher levels of bilirubin and result in jaundice.
     
  3. Neonatal Hypocalcaemia (Option C): Infants of diabetic mothers are at an increased risk of hypocalcemia, or low calcium levels in the blood. This can occur due to various metabolic imbalances associated with the maternal diabetic environment.
     
  4. Neonatal Hyperglycemia (Answer D): This is less likely in infants of diabetic mothers and thus is the correct answer. In fact, neonatal hypoglycemia is a more common issue in these infants. Due to high insulin levels in response to maternal hyperglycemia, these infants can have low blood sugar levels after birth once the maternal glucose supply is cut off.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal complications (Seen because of Pedersen Hypothesis)

 

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Polycythemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Cardiomyopathy

 

Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Caudal regression syndrome is a commonly associated anomaly seen in diabetes
The risk of anomalies in the fetus is inversely proportional to the level of HBA1c.
Folic acid in a dose of 5 mg/day started in the preconception period will not reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

questions.text: A 36-year diabetic woman on insulin is planning conception. She is worried about the risk of fetal congenital anomalies and visits for preconception counseling. Which of the following is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

 

  • The most common anomaly in diabetic mothers is congenital heart disease
  • The most specific (albeit rare) anomaly in diabetic mothers is caudal regression syndrome (mermaid syndrome)
  • The higher the HBA1C level preconceptionally; the higher the risk of fetal anomalies
  • Both metformin and glyburide cross the placenta but evidence has shown they are safe

 

Let's analyse each option:

 

Option A. Caudal Regression Syndrome is Commonly Associated with Diabetes: Caudal regression syndrome, a rare disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine, is indeed more common in infants born to mothers with pre-existing diabetes, particularly those with poor glycemic control. However, it's important to note that while the risk is increased, the condition itself is still relatively rare.

 

Option B. Risk of Anomalies Inversely Proportional to HbA1c Levels: This statement is partially true. Higher HbA1c levels, indicating poorer blood sugar control, are associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies. However, this option is slightly misleading as it implies a direct inverse proportionality, which is an oversimplification. The relationship between HbA1c and risk is significant, but other factors also play a role.

 

Option C. Folic Acid at 5 mg/day Will Not Reduce Risk of Neural Tube Defects: This statement is incorrect. Folic acid supplementation, typically at a dose of 400-800 micrograms per day, is known to reduce the risk of neural tube defects. In some cases, such as in women with a history of a child with a neural tube defect or those on certain medications like antiepileptics, a higher dose like 5 mg/day might be recommended.

 

Option D. Metformin and Glyburide Safe in Pregnancy (Answer D): Metformin and glyburide are oral hypoglycemic agents that can indeed cross the placenta. However, current evidence suggests that they are safe to use during pregnancy and are often prescribed to manage gestational diabetes or pre-existing diabetes in pregnant women. This is the correct statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While higher HbA1c levels are associated with increased risks, the use of certain oral hypoglycemic agents like metformin and glyburide is considered safe during pregnancy.
  • Additionally, folic acid supplementation is important for reducing the risk of neural tube defects.

 

Ref:  Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Elective cesarean delivery regardless of the presence of lesions at the time of labor
Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor
Vaginal delivery with administration of antiviral prophylaxis
Induction of labor at 37 weeks to reduce the risk of neonatal infection

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with primary genital herpes infection. What is the most appropriate management regarding delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor

 

Explanation: If a woman has primary genital herpes before pregnancy or in early pregnancy and has no active lesions at the time of labor, vaginal delivery is usually safe. However, if she has active genital lesions or prodromal symptoms at the onset of labor, a cesarean delivery is recommended to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If there is active genital herpes at term, cesarean section has to be done

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: 6-10 weeks
12-20 weeks
24-28 weeks
36 – 40 weeks

questions.text: The highest risk of developing congenital varicella syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 12-20 weeks

  • Congenital Varicella Syndrome is characterized by
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

 

  • The highest risk of fetal infection is between 13-20 weeks.

Ref: Page no 1212-1213, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: FBS ≥ 126 mg/dL
PPBS ≥ 140 mg/dl
HbA1C ≥ 6.5 %
RBS ≥ 200 mg/dL

questions.text: As per IADPSG recommendations, pre-gestational diabetes is diagnosed in the 1st antenatal visit by all of the values given below except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PPBS ≥ 140 mg/dl

 

IADPSG Recommendations: Testing in 2 phases

 

1st Phase: To test for overt diabetes (which the woman may be unaware of)

 

  • Done in the 1st trimester (early antenatal visit)
  • Test using HbA1C/ FBS/ RBS
  • FBS ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • HbA1C ≥ 6.5 %
  • RBS ≥ 200 mg/dL (but this should be confirmed by FBS/ HbA1C)

 

2nd Phase: To test for GDM

 

  • Done between 24 – 28 weeks
  • 75g GTT
  • Fasting: 92/ 1h – 180/ 2h – 153
  • Any one value abnormal: Enough to diagnose GDM

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In diagnosing pre-gestational diabetes during the first antenatal visit, IADPSG guidelines include criteria such as a fasting blood sugar of ≥ 126 mg/dL, an HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%, or a random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL.

 

 Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 34 weeks
37 weeks
38 weeks
40 weeks

questions.text: A 34-year Primi who is a known diabetic on insulin presents at 34 weeks pregnancy.  On examination, the uterus is 34 weeks and FHR is 140 bpm. Her blood sugar is well controlled. At what period of gestation should her delivery be planned?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 38 weeks

 

In Overt Diabetes (Pre-gestational diabetes) on insulin, Plan delivery at 38 weeks OR earlier if

 

  • Poorly controlled sugars
  • Non reassuring fetal status

 

In Gestational Diabetes
 

  • Plan delivery at 40 weeks
  • Avoid past dates
  • Anticipate shoulder dystocia
  • Prophylactic LSCS in diabetic women if estimated fetal weight > 4.5 Kg

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Overt Diabetes (Pre-gestational diabetes) on insulin, delivery is planned at 38 weeks.
  • Earlier delivery may be planned if there are poorly controlled sugars or non-reassuring fetal status

 

Ref: Page no 1107, Williams Obstetrics, Page no 509, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Dutta

choices.text: Anemia
Antepartum hemorrhage
Gestational Diabetes mellitus
Thrombocytopenia

questions.text: An infant was born at 36 weeks of pregnancy with a birthweight 4.5 kg as shown in the image.  Which of the following conditions is associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gestational Diabetes mellitus

 

The clinical scenario shown is of macrosomia.

Macrosomia is defined as estimated fetal weight > 90th percentile for that gestational age

 

  • Causes of macrosomia are.
    • Gestational Diabetes mellitus
    • Maternal obesity
    • Previous baby with macrosomia
    • Post-term pregnancy
    • Excessive weight gain in pregnancy
  • Anemia and APH are associated with fetal growth restriction
  • Thrombocytopenia has no association with fetal weight

 

Let's briefly explain each option:

 

Option A. Anemia: Anemia refers to a deficiency of hemoglobin in the blood and is not typically associated with macrosomia or a large birthweight.

 

Option B. Antepartum hemorrhage: Antepartum hemorrhage refers to bleeding during pregnancy before the onset of labor and is not directly associated with the infant's birthweight.

 

Option C. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM): Infants born to mothers with GDM are at an increased risk of macrosomia, which can have implications for both mother and baby. Proper management of GDM during pregnancy is essential to reduce the risk of complications.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by a low platelet count in the blood and is not directly related to the infant's birthweight.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The birth of an infant with a birthweight of 4.5 kg at 36 weeks of pregnancy is suggestive of macrosomia.
  • Macrosomia is commonly associated with maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), which can lead to larger birthweights in babies.

choices.text: It is done in the fasting state
Patients with a positive GCT are subjected to a GTT (Glucose tolerance test)
The lower the threshold taken in a GCT, the higher the sensitivity for detection of gestational diabetes mellitus
It is done between 24 – 28 weeks

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents to the OPD at 24 weeks. She is advised to get a Glucose Challenge Test done. All are true regarding the glucose challenge test (GCT) except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is done in the fasting state.

 

Glucose Challenge Test (GCT)

 

  • Done at 24 – 28 weeks.
  • Plasma glucose is measured 1 h after a 50g glucose load irrespective of prandial state.
  • Value of 
    • ≥ 140 mg/ dl: screen positive: subjected to glucose tolerance test (GTT)
    • ≥ 200: Diagnosed as GDM (No need for GTT)
    • The lower the threshold of GCT, the higher the sensitivity and lower the specificity for detecting gestational diabetes.

 

Let's evaluate the options:

 

Option A. It is done in the fasting state (Answer A): This statement is incorrect, and therefore the answer. The GCT is a non-fasting test. The pregnant woman is given a glucose solution to drink, and her blood sugar level is tested after one hour. The fasting state is not required for this test, distinguishing it from the Glucose Tolerance Test (GTT).

 

Option B. Patients with a positive GCT are subjected to a GTT  (glucose tolerance test): This statement is correct. If the GCT results are positive or above a certain threshold, it suggests the possibility of gestational diabetes, and the patient is then advised to undergo a GTT for confirmation. The GTT is a more comprehensive test involving fasting and multiple blood sugar measurements over a few hours.

 

Option C. The lower the threshold in a GCT, the higher the sensitivity for detection of GDM: This is also correct. Lowering the threshold level for GCT results means more women will be classified as having a positive screen, increasing the sensitivity of the test. However, this might also lead to a higher false-positive rate, where women without GDM are identified as potentially having it.

 

Option D. It is done between 24 – 28 weeks: This is a true statement. The GCT is typically performed between 24 and 28 weeks of gestation. This timing is chosen because gestational diabetes usually develops around this period in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glucose Challenge Test is a non-fasting, initial screening test for gestational diabetes conducted between 24 to 28 weeks of pregnancy.
  • A positive GCT necessitates further testing with a Glucose Tolerance Test. Adjusting the threshold level of the GCT can impact its sensitivity and specificity for detecting gestational diabetes.

 

Ref: Page no 262, DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: The patient has diabetes
The patient has a urine infection
The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy
The patient’s urine sample is contaminated.

questions.text: During a routine antenatal visit, an 24-year G1 at 20 weeks gestational age undergoes a urinalysis. The dipstick done indicates the presence of glycosuria. All other parameters of the urine test are normal. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of sugar detected in the urine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy

 

In pregnancy, the increased GFR and the impaired tubular reabsorption capacity for filtered glucose occurs; hence glycosuria is a normal finding in pregnancy.

 

Let's explain each of the options :

 

Option A. The patient has diabetes: Glycosuria is a potential indicator of diabetes, but not a diagnostic of GDM and further diagnostic tests like fasting blood sugar (FBS), oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), or HbA1c may be required to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option B. The patient has a urine infection: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) can sometimes cause glycosuria due to the presence of bacteria in the urinary tract that can ferment glucose, leading to its appearance in the urine. If a urine infection is suspected, further tests such as a urine culture and sensitivity should be performed to confirm the presence of infection.

 

Option C. The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy: During pregnancy, some women may develop mild glycosuria as a normal physiological response to hormonal changes. This is known as "physiological glycosuria" and is not associated with diabetes or other medical conditions. It is a benign condition in pregnancy and does not necessarily indicate diabetes. It typically resolves after pregnancy. Monitoring blood glucose levels may still be advisable to rule out diabetes.

 

Option D. The patient’s urine sample is contaminated: Contamination of the urine sample with glucose-containing substances (e.g., vaginal secretions) can lead to false-positive results for glycosuria. Careful collection and handling of urine samples are essential to ensure accurate test results. Contamination should be minimized to obtain reliable urinalysis results.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Physiological glycosuria, a normal response to hormonal changes in pregnancy, may lead to the presence of glucose in the urine without underlying diabetes. It is essential to consider other factors, such as diabetes, urinary tract infections, and sample contamination, and perform further tests if necessary to determine the cause of glycosuria.

 

Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Pre-gestational diabetes
Gestational diabetes mellitus
Effect of valproate
Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pre-gestational diabetes

 

  • This image is mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia
  • It is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • The most common anomaly associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).

 

Let's examine each of the options:

 

  1. Pre-gestational Diabetes: This refers to diabetes that exists before pregnancy. Women with pre-gestational diabetes have a higher risk of giving birth to babies with congenital anomalies, including neural tube defects and cardiovascular malformations.
     
  2. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM): This type of diabetes develops during pregnancy and generally resolves after delivery. While GDM can lead to several complications, such as macrosomia or hypoglycemia in the baby, it is not typically associated with congenital anomalies.
     
  3. Effect of Valproate: Valproate use during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, is associated with an increased risk of several congenital malformations, including neural tube defects, cleft palate, and heart defects.
     
  4. Hypertensive on ACE Inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are not recommended during pregnancy, as they can lead to fetal complications such as renal damage. However, there is no known association between the use of ACE inhibitors and sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • The most common anomaly associated with pre-gestational diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).

 

Ref: Page 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: CMV
HPV
Rubella
Tetanus

questions.text: A 25 y woman is planning to conceive. She is unsure of her childhood vaccination status. Which of the following vaccines should she receive before conceiving?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rubella

  • Pre-pregnancy, if rubella immunization status Is unknown, serological evaluation is done (IgG rubella) and if IgG Rubella is negative, then vaccination with rubella vaccine is recommended.
  • Very important! Conception is to be avoided for 1 month after vaccination with rubella as it is a live attenuated vaccine

Ref: Page no 647, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
HELLP syndrome
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
Acute viral hepatitis

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with mildly elevated liver enzymes and itching over her body. She has no history of liver disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

 

Explanation: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy typically presents in the second or third trimester with itching and elevated liver enzymes but without significant liver damage. It's characterized by impaired bile flow and can lead to adverse fetal outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: This is diagnosed by the Swansea criteria. Patients with AFLP usually present in the 3rd trimester with jaundice, abdominal pain, vomiting. There is altered liver function along with worsening renal and coagulation parameters. Hypoglycemia is typically seen.
  • Option B: HELLP Syndrome: This is a form of severe preeclampsia so a h/o high BP would usually be mentioned. HELLP syndrome is a triad of Hemolysis, Elevated Liver Enzymes and Low Platelets.
  • Option D: Acute viral hepatitis: This can be seen in any trimester. There is a history of fever, constitutional symptoms and jaundice. Serum bilirubin is raised and AST and ALT are very highly raised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference- Page no 270, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Malaria
Parvovirus
Rubella
Varicella

questions.text: Which of the following infections can cause fetal hydrops?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parvovirus

  • Parvovirus B19 infects rapidly dividing cells
  • It is cytotoxic for erythroid progenitor cells
  • Parvovirus B19 infections in pregnancy can causes fetal anemia, hydrops and fetal death especially if infection happens within 20 weeks of pregnancy

Ref: Page no 654, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: FBS & PPBS
HBA1C
Urine routine for sugar
GCT

questions.text: A 34-year Primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her mother is a diabetic and she is screened for Diabetes at her 8 weeks antenatal visit. What was the most likely screening method used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HBA1C

 

  • As per IADPSG guidelines, testing for Diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy is by HBA1c or an FBS or RBS.  (For Overt diabetes Hba1C > 6.5 % or FBS >126 mg/dl or RBS >200 mg/dl)
  • Urine for sugar is not sensitive for testing for Diabetes in pregnancy as physiologic glycosuria can be present
  • GCT is not used for Diabetes screening in the first trimester. It is part of screening of GDM between 24 – 28 weeks.

 

Let's look at each option separately :

 

Option A. FBS & PPBS: FBS and PPBS are essential for monitoring blood sugar levels in pregnant women, but both together may typically be performed later in pregnancy or when there is suspicion of gestational diabetes. IADPSG Consensus Panel members favored use of any available certified laboratory measure of glucose (Fasting OR Random plasma glucose OR Hb A1C) for initial detection of possible cases.

 

Option B. HBA1C (Hemoglobin A1C): HBA1C is a blood test that provides an average of a person's blood sugar levels over the past two to three months. It is a valuable screening tool for diabetes, including in pregnant women. HBA1C can be used as an early screening method for diabetes in pregnant women, especially when there is a family history of diabetes.

 

Option C. Urine Routine for Sugar: Urine routine for sugar is not the primary method for diabetes screening in pregnant women. It may be used for general monitoring but is less reliable than blood tests.

 

Option D. GCT (Glucose Challenge Test): GCT is typically performed later in pregnancy to screen for gestational diabetes and is not the primary method for early screening in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective (Summary):

 

Hemoglobin A1C (HBA1C) is the most likely screening method used for diabetes at the 8-week antenatal visit, especially when there is a family history of diabetes. It provides a longer-term view of blood sugar control.

 

Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Glyburide
Insulin
Metformin
Pioglitazone

questions.text: Which hypoglycemic drug cannot be used in diabetes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pioglitazone

 

Drugs safe in pregnancy are:

 

OHA – Metformin (Category B) and Glyburide (Category C) and Insulin

 

  • Both Metformin and Glyburide cross the placenta
  • Metformin:
    • Biguanide, acts by promoting glucose uptake in the periphery and the liver
    • Suppresses hepatic glucose production
    • Hypoglycemia not seen
    • Started at 250 mg TDs; Max: 2500 mg/day
  • Glyburide
    • Increases insulin secretion
    • Safe after 15 weeks
    • Dose: 2.5 mg BD; may 20 mg/ day
    • Increased incidence of neonatal and maternal hypoglycemia with glyburide

 

Let's discuss each option:

 

  1. Glyburide: Glyburide is a sulfonylurea class of medication that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is classified as Category C by the FDA, meaning that animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks. Glyburide does cross the placenta but has been used in pregnancy, particularly in the second and third trimesters. However, it may increase the risk of neonatal and maternal hypoglycemia.
     
  2. Insulin: Insulin is the most common and preferred treatment for managing diabetes in pregnancy, especially if the diabetes is pre-gestational. It does not cross the placenta and therefore does not pose a direct risk to the fetal development. Different types of insulin can be used to manage blood sugar levels effectively during pregnancy.
     
  3. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases glucose uptake in the periphery. Classified as Category B by the FDA, it suggests that there is no evidence of risk in human pregnancy. Metformin does cross the placenta, but studies have not shown an increased risk of birth defects or other pregnancy complications. It's often used in gestational diabetes and in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) who are trying to conceive.
     
  4. Pioglitazone (Answer D): Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinedione class of drugs, which is generally not recommended during pregnancy. The safety of pioglitazone in pregnancy has not been established, and there are concerns about its potential effects on the fetus. Therefore, it is usually avoided in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When treating diabetes in pregnancy, insulin is the preferred medication due to its safety profile.
     
  • Metformin and glyburide can also be used, albeit with some caution and monitoring.
     
  • Pioglitazone, on the other hand, is not recommended for use during pregnancy due to the lack of sufficient safety data and potential fetal risks.

 

Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Insulin secretion increases in pregnancy
Insulin resistance is due to placental hormones
Maternal insulin can cross the placenta
The fetus starts secreting insulin at 12 weeks

questions.text: All are true regarding physiology of pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maternal insulin can cross the placenta

 

Carbohydrate metabolism in pregnancy

 

  • Pregnancy is a diabetogenic state associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance
  • Insulin resistance is due to placental hormones (human placental lactogen, estrogen, progesterone, cortisol)
  • Insulin secretion increases during pregnancy
  • Insulin resistance is maximum between 24-28 weeks of pregnancy
  • Maternal insulin cannot cross the placenta
  • The fetus starts secreting insulin by 12 weeks

 

Let's explore each of the given options:

 

  1. Insulin Secretion Increases in Pregnancy (Option A): True. During pregnancy, the body's need for insulin increases due to the greater demand for glucose by both the mother and the growing fetus. The pancreas typically responds by increasing insulin production to meet these needs.
     
  2. Insulin Resistance is Due to Placental Hormones (Option B): This statement is also true. Pregnancy is characterized by a state of insulin resistance, which worsens as pregnancy progresses. This insulin resistance is primarily driven by placental hormones such as human placental lactogen, progesterone, and others. These hormones ensure that enough glucose is available for the fetus by making the mother's body less responsive to insulin.
     
  3. Maternal Insulin Can Cross the Placenta (Answer C): This is false, and therefore the correct answer. Maternal insulin does not cross the placenta. The fetus produces its own insulin starting from around 10-12 weeks of gestation. The mother's insulin does not enter the fetal circulation; instead, the glucose crosses the placenta, and the fetus produces insulin in response to this glucose.
     
  4. The Fetus Starts Securing Insu lin at 12 Weeks (Option D): This is a true statement. The fetal pancreas begins to function and produce insulin around the 12th week of gestation. Fetal insulin plays a crucial role in fetal growth and development, especially in the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, there is an increase in insulin secretion due to increased insulin resistance, largely driven by placental hormones. However, maternal insulin does not cross the placenta; the fetus produces its own insulin in response to glucose that crosses from the maternal circulation.

 

Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications
Maternal insulin can cross the placenta resulting in neonatal hypoglycemia
Maternal hyperglycemia results in an increased incidence of congenital anomalies
Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in a lower incidence of respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text: Pederson’s hypothesis states that:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications.

 

Let's look at each option:

 

  1. Maternal Hyperglycemia Leading to Fetal Hyperglycemia and Fetal Hyperinsulinemia (Answer A): This is true.  Pederson's hypothesis primarily states that maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, as glucose crosses the placenta. In response to this excess glucose, the fetal pancreas produces more insulin. This overproduction of insulin can lead to several complications in the fetus, such as macrosomia, increased risk of birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia after birth.
     
  2. Maternal Insulin Crossing the Placenta Resulting in Neonatal Hypoglycemia (Option B): Incorrect. Insulin, being a large molecule, does not cross the placenta. Therefore, maternal insulin levels do not directly affect the fetus. The hypoglycemia seen in neonates of diabetic mothers is typically due to the baby's own insulin response to high glucose levels in utero.
     
  3. Maternal Hyperglycemia Results in Increased Incidence of Congenital Anomalies (Option C): While this statement is true, it is not what Pederson's hypothesis is about. Poorly controlled diabetes in the mother can increase the risk of various congenital anomalies in the fetus, particularly if the hyperglycemia occurs during the critical first trimester of organogenesis.
     
  4. Fetal Hyperinsulinemia Results in a Lower Incidence of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Option D): This option is incorrect. In fact, infants of diabetic mothers, especially those with poor glycaemic control, are at an increased risk of respiratory distress syndrome. This is due to delayed lung maturity, partly influenced by insulin's antagonistic effect on surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pederson's hypothesis emphasizes the direct impact of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus, leading to fetal hyperglycemia and resultant fetal hyperinsulinemia.
  •  This cascade underscores the importance of strict glycemic control in pregnant women with diabetes to prevent fetal complications, including macrosomia, birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia.

 

 

Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Consider termination of pregnancy
Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration
IV Acyclovir
Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG)

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1L1 teacher presents at 22 weeks with fever and rash since 2 days. She gives history of contact with a child in her class who had chicken pox 10 days earlier. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration

Chickenpox in Pregnancy

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

choices.text: Malformations
Polyhydramnios
Obesity
Previous history of macrosomia

questions.text: Which is NOT seen in gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Malformations

 

Congenital anomalies are NOT SEEN with GDM

 

Congenital anomalies are seen Only with Overt DM

 

  • HbA1C > 10 in the 1st trimester: Associated with a higher risk for congenital malformations
  • Most Common system involved – cardiac
  • Most common anomaly seen in GDM – VSD
  • Most characteristic anomaly (very rare)– Mermaid syndrome/ sirenomelia

 

Let's briefly explain the other options:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios refers to an excess of amniotic fluid in the amniotic sac during pregnancy. It can be a complication associated with GDM, as elevated blood sugar levels in the baby can lead to increased urine production, which, in turn, can contribute to polyhydramnios.

 

Option C. Obesity: Obesity is a risk factor for the development of GDM. Women who are overweight or obese before pregnancy are at a higher risk of developing GDM.

 

Option D. Previous history of macrosomia: A previous history of giving birth to a macrosomic (large birthweight) baby is a risk factor for GDM. Macrosomia is a common outcome of GDM, and women who have previously experienced it are at an increased risk of developing GDM in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically not associated with congenital malformations
  •  GDM can lead to complications such as polyhydramnios, especially if blood sugar levels are uncontrolled during pregnancy.
  • Obesity is a risk factor for the development of GDM and a previous history of giving birth to a macrosomic baby increases the risk of GDM in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Ref:  Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Oral antihypertensive therapy
Platelet transfusion
Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour
Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman presents at 29 weeks gestation with headache and a blood pressure of 160/110 mm Hg. Investigations reveal 2+ proteinuria on dipstick, an elevated SGOT and SGPT and a platelet count of 80,000/mm3. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour

 

Even if hemolysis is not established, thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes point toward severe features in pre eclampsia, which needs to be treated with Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour 

 

  • HELLP syndrome is a complication of pre-eclampsia and includes
    • Hemolysis
    • Elevated liver enzymes
    • Thromobocytopenia
  • HELLP is an indication for termination of pregnancy.
  • MgSO4 also needs to be given for both seizure prophylaxis and will also provide neuro-protection of the neonate f/b delivery of the patient.

 

Severe features in pre eclampsia need to be started on magnesium sulphate therapy

 

 

 

Contraindications to Conservative management in severe preeclampsia (This means deliver asap in the following scenarios):

 

Remember by the mnemonic DELIVER Asap

D: Fetal Distress

E: Eclampsia

L: HELLP

I: DIC

V: non-viable fetus (extremely preterm)

E: pulmonary Edema

R: Renal failure

Asap: Abruption

 

Let's analyse each management option:

 

Option A. Oral Antihypertensive Therapy: While managing high blood pressure is crucial in preeclampsia, this option alone does not address the other severe features of the condition like proteinuria, liver dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option B. Platelet Transfusion: In the context of preeclampsia, platelet transfusion is not typically a primary management strategy unless there's a risk of severe bleeding or if surgery (like cesarean section) is planned and the platelet count is critically low.

 

Option C. Magnesium Sulphate Therapy and Induction of Labour: This is the correct option. Given the severity of symptoms and the potential risks to both the mother and the fetus, management often involves delivery (the definitive treatment for preeclampsia), along with magnesium sulphate to prevent eclamptic seizures.

 

Option D. Intravenous Immunoglobulin Therapy: IVIG is not a treatment for preeclampsia and does not address the immediate risks associated with this condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases with severe features, like significant hypertension, proteinuria, liver dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia, the primary management is to stabilize the mother and expedite delivery, as the condition typically resolves only after delivery. Magnesium sulphate is essential for seizure prophylaxis.

 

Ref: Page no 1852, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL
FBS < 90 mg/dl, 1h PP < 145 mg/ dl, 2h < 125 mg/dl
FBS < 105 mg/dl, 1h PP < 140 mg/dl, 2h PP < 120 mg/dl
FBS < 95 mg/dl, 1h PP < 120 mg/ dl, 2h PP < 140 mg/dl

questions.text: Target blood glucose levels for women with gestational diabetes on treatment are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL

 

The target blood glucose levels in treatment of diabetes in pregnancy is:

 

  • FBS < 95 mg/dL
  •  1h PP < 140 mg/dL
  •  2h PP < 120 mg/dL

 

These targets are designed to balance the need for tight glucose control to prevent fetal complications while minimizing the risk of maternal hypoglycemia. It's important for women with gestational diabetes to monitor their blood glucose levels regularly and adhere to their treatment plan, which may include diet modifications, exercise, and possibly medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the management of gestational diabetes, target blood glucose levels are set to ensure both maternal and fetal well-being. The recommended targets are:
    •  fasting blood sugar less than 95 mg/dL
    • 1-hour postprandial less than 140 mg/dL
    • 2-hour postprandial less than 120 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 264, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: > 4000g
> 4500g
> 5000g
> 5500g

questions.text: Elective cesarean delivery is indicated in a diabetic woman if the estimated fetal weight is
questions.solution:
Ans. B. > 4500g

 

As per the ACOG (to prevent shoulder dystocia)

 

  • Elective LSCS is done in non-diabetic women if the estimated fetal weight is > 5kg
  • Elective LSCS is done in diabetic women if the estimated fetal weight is > 4.5kg

 

The increased risk in diabetic pregnancies is attributed to the higher incidence of fetal macrosomia, often a result of poorly controlled maternal blood glucose levels. Macrosomia increases the risk of complications during vaginal delivery, including shoulder dystocia, where the baby's shoulder becomes lodged behind the mother's pelvic bone during delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per ACOG, for diabetic pregnant women, an elective cesarean delivery is recommended if the estimated fetal weight exceeds 4.5 kg.
  • This is in contrast to non-diabetic women, where the threshold for an elective cesarean is set at an estimated fetal weight of more than 5 kg.
  • The lower threshold for diabetic women is due to the increased risk of macrosomia and related birth complications, including shoulder dystocia.

 

Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition
